statement.p: Let R = \{(1,1),(2,2),(1,2),(2,1),(1,3),(3,3),(3,1),(4,4)\} be a relation on the set \{1,2,3,4\}. Is R an equivalence relation? Which properties (reflexive, symmetric, transitive) hold/fail?

Let S be the set of differentiable functions from \mathbb{R} to \mathbb{R}, and let \star be the relation f \star g \Leftrightarrow f'(x) = g'(x). Is \star an equivalence relation? If it is, describe its equivalence classes.
Let \sim be the following relation on \mathbb{Z}: m \sim n \Leftrightarrow 4 \mid (m^2 - n^2). Is \sim an equivalence relation? If it is, describe its equivalence classes.
What are the equivalence classes of $R$?
If R is an equivalence relation on the set S, and a, b \in S such that a \in [b], show that [a] = [b]. Do not use or .

Compute the remainder when
3^{333} is divided by 100
5^{444} is divided by 11
2^{888} is divided by 8
9^{999} is divided by 99
Without using induction, prove that 11^{n+2} + 12^{2n+1} is divisible by 133 for any n \in \mathbb{N}.
Let N be the product of any k consecutive natural numbers. Prove k! \mid N.

Find the multiplicative inverse of each integer b modulo m:
b = 4, m = 5
b = 13, m = 76
b = 33, m = 7
b = 10, m = 9
b = 100, m = 999
Prove that if \gcd(a,n) \nmid b, then ax \equiv b \Mod{n} has no solutions.
Let a \in \mathbb{N} and suppose p is prime. Prove that a^2 \equiv 1 \Mod{p} if and only if a \equiv 1 \Mod{p} or a \equiv -1 \Mod{p}.
If m = 2^k is a power of 2, explain how you could use repeated squaring to compute a^m \mmod{n} for any n. Then apply your method to compute 10^{32} \mmod 41.
If m is not a power of 2, explain how you could use the results of to compute a^m \mmod{n}for any n. Then apply your method to compute 17^{26} \mmod 44.

hint.p: Express m as a sum of powers of two.

statement.p: Prove \phi(p^kq^l) = \left(p^k-p^{k-1}\right)\left(q^l - q^{l-1}\right) for primes p and q, and k,l\in\mathbb{N}.

Find the smallest positive integer y such that
y divided by 9 leaves a remainder of 7, and
y divided by 10 leaves a remainder of 9.
Solve the system of congruences \begin{cases} x \equiv 2 \Mod{3} \\ x \equiv 2 \Mod{7} \\ x \equiv 1 \Mod{13} \end{cases} using the method outlined in .
